lessons.title: 0.1 What is Programming?
lessons.content:
# What is Programming?

Programming is writing instructions for computers to perform specific tasks.

## Key Concepts

â€¢ **Algorithm**: Step-by-step procedure to solve a problem

â€¢ **Logic**: The reasoning behind the steps

â€¢ **Code**: Instructions written in a programming language

## Why Java?

Java is:
â€¢ **Platform Independent**: Run on Windows, Mac, Linux without changes
â€¢ **Object-Oriented**: Organizes code into reusable objects
â€¢ **Secure**: Built-in security features
â€¢ **Widely Used**: Netflix, Google, Amazon, Twitter use Java

options: Code can run on any OS without rewriting
Code is faster on some platforms
quizQuestions.explanation: Write once, run anywhere - Java code compiled once runs on any machine.

lessons.title: 0.2 How Java Works (JDK, JRE, JVM)
lessons.content:
# How Java Works

## The Three Components

### ðŸ”¥ JVM (Java Virtual Machine)

â€¢ **What it is**: Abstract computing machine that executes bytecode

â€¢ **Role**: Runs compiled Java programs

â€¢ **Key Benefit**: Platform-independent execution

### âš¡ JRE (Java Runtime Environment)

â€¢ **Contains**: JVM + Libraries

â€¢ **Purpose**: Run Java applications (not develop)

â€¢ **User Type**: End users

### ðŸ’  JDK (Java Development Kit)

â€¢ **Contains**: JRE + Compiler + Tools

â€¢ **Purpose**: Write, compile, debug Java programs

â€¢ **Tools**: javac, java, javadoc, jdb

## Compilation Process

```
.java file â†’ javac compiler â†’ .class file (bytecode) â†’ JVM â†’ Execution
```
lessons.expectedOutput:
JDK contains JRE + Compiler
JRE contains JVM + Libraries

quizQuestions.explanation: JVM is the Java Virtual Machine that executes bytecode.

lessons.title: 0.3 Data Types in Java
lessons.content:
# Primitive Data Types in Java

## Integer Types

### ðŸ”¥ int (Integer)

â€¢ **Size**: 4 bytes (32 bits)

â€¢ **Range**: -2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647

â€¢ **Purpose**: Whole numbers

```java
int age = 25;
int score = 100;
```

### ðŸ“Š long (Large Integer)

â€¢ **Size**: 8 bytes (64 bits)

â€¢ **Purpose**: Very large numbers

â€¢ **Note**: Suffix 'L' required

```java
long population = 7800000000L;
```

### ðŸ“ˆ short (Medium Integer)

â€¢ **Size**: 2 bytes (16 bits)

â€¢ **Range**: -32,768 to 32,767

```java
short year = 2024;
```

### ðŸ“‰ byte (Small Integer)

â€¢ **Size**: 1 byte (8 bits)

â€¢ **Range**: -128 to 127

```java
byte age = 25;
```

## Decimal Types

### âš¡ double (High Precision)

â€¢ **Size**: 8 bytes (64 bits)

â€¢ **Precision**: 15-17 significant digits

â€¢ **Default for decimals**

```java
double pi = 3.14159265;
Double salary = 50000.50;
```

### ðŸ’  float (Lower Precision)

â€¢ **Size**: 4 bytes (32 bits)

â€¢ **Precision**: 6-7 significant digits

â€¢ **Note**: Suffix 'f' required

```java
float temperature = 36.5f;
```

## Character & Boolean

### ðŸ”¤ char (Character)

â€¢ **Size**: 2 bytes (16 bits)

â€¢ **Range**: Unicode (0 to 65535)

```java
char grade = 'A';
char symbol = '@';
```

### âœ… boolean (True/False)

â€¢ **Size**: 1 byte

â€¢ **Values**: true or false

```java
boolean isProgrammer = true;
boolean isStudent = false;
```

## Reference Type

### ðŸ“ String (Text)

â€¢ **Size**: Variable

â€¢ **Purpose**: Text sequences

```java
String name = "GenSpark";
String message = "Welcome to Java";
```

## Quick Reference

**int** - 4 bytes - Whole numbers

**long** - 8 bytes - Large integers (suffix L)

**float** - 4 bytes - Decimals (suffix f)

**double** - 8 bytes - Decimals (high precision)

**char** - 2 bytes - Single character

**boolean** - 1 byte - true/false

**String** - Variable - Text
lessons.expectedOutput:
Name: Arjun
Age: 25
Salary: 50000.5
Grade: A
Is Programmer: true

quizQuestions.text: Which data type uses 8 bytes and has 15-17 digit precision?
quizQuestions.explanation: double is 8 bytes with 15-17 significant digits precision.

lessons.title: 1.1 Operators & Expressions
lessons.content:
# Operators in Java

## Arithmetic Operators

â€¢ **+** Addition: `10 + 5 = 15`

â€¢ **-** Subtraction: `10 - 5 = 5`

â€¢ *** Multiplication: `10 * 5 = 50`

â€¢ **/** Division: `10 / 5 = 2`

â€¢ **%** Modulus (remainder): `10 % 3 = 1`

â€¢ **++** Increment: `a++` (post) or `++a` (pre)

â€¢ **--** Decrement: `a--` or `--a`

## Relational Operators

Return true or false

â€¢ **==** Equal to

â€¢ **!=** Not equal to

â€¢ **>** Greater than

â€¢ **<** Less than

â€¢ **>=** Greater than or equal

â€¢ **<=** Less than or equal

## Logical Operators

â€¢ **&&** AND (both true)

â€¢ **||** OR (at least one true)

â€¢ **!** NOT (reverses value)

## Assignment Operators

â€¢ **=** Assign

â€¢ **+=** Add and assign

â€¢ **-=** Subtract and assign

â€¢ *** =** Multiply and assign
lessons.expectedOutput:
a + b = 30
a > b = true
(a > b) && (b > 5) = true

quizQuestions.explanation: Modulus returns remainder: 10 divided by 3 is 3 remainder 1.

lessons.title: 2.2 Recursion
lessons.content:
# Recursion in Java

A method calling itself to solve a problem.

## Key Components

â€¢ **Base Case**: Condition to stop recursion

â€¢ **Recursive Call**: Method calling itself with different parameters

## Example: Factorial

```java
public static int factorial(int n) {
    if (n <= 1) {           // Base case
        return 1;
    }
    return n * factorial(n - 1);  // Recursive call
}

factorial(5) = 5 * 4 * 3 * 2 * 1 = 120
```

## Example: Sum of Numbers

```java
public static int sum(int n) {
    if (n <= 0) {
        return 0;  // Base case
    }
    return n + sum(n - 1);  // Recursive call
}

sum(5) = 5 + sum(4) = 5 + 4 + 3 + 2 + 1 = 15
```

## How Recursion Works

1. Call function with parameter
2. If base case met, return value
3. Otherwise, call function again with modified parameter
4. Return combined results

quizQuestions.text: What is the base case in recursion?
quizQuestions.explanation: Base case stops recursion; without it, infinite loop occurs.

Index out of bounds!

lessons.title: 6.1 ArrayList & LinkedList

quizQuestions.text: What is the main difference between ArrayList and LinkedList?
options: LinkedList is faster for random access
ArrayList is faster for random access
quizQuestions.explanation: ArrayList uses arrays so random access is O(1), LinkedList is O(n).

lessons.title: 6.2 HashMap & TreeMap

quizQuestions.text: What is the main advantage of HashMap over TreeMap?
quizQuestions.explanation: HashMap has O(1) access while TreeMap has O(log n).

lessons.title: 7.1 String Methods & Immutability
lessons.content:
# Strings in Java

Strings are immutable sequences of characters.

## String Creation

```java
String str1 = "Hello";              // String literal
String str2 = new String("Hello");  // String object
```

## Common String Methods

â€¢ **length()**: Get length

â€¢ **charAt(index)**: Get character at index

â€¢ **substring(start, end)**: Extract substring

â€¢ **indexOf(char)**: Find position

â€¢ **toUpperCase()**: Convert to uppercase

â€¢ **toLowerCase()**: Convert to lowercase

â€¢ **trim()**: Remove whitespace

â€¢ **replace(old, new)**: Replace characters

â€¢ **split(delimiter)**: Split string

â€¢ **equals(str)**: Compare strings

â€¢ **startsWith(prefix)**: Check prefix

â€¢ **endsWith(suffix)**: Check suffix

```java
String str = "Hello World";
System.out.println(str.length());        // 11
System.out.println(str.toUpperCase());   // HELLO WORLD
System.out.println(str.substring(0, 5)); // Hello
System.out.println(str.indexOf('W'));    // 6
```

## String Immutability

Once created, string cannot be changed.

```java
String str = "Java";
str = str + " Programming";  // Creates new string
```

## StringBuilder (Mutable)

For efficient string concatenation.

```java
StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
sb.append("Hello");
sb.append(" ");
sb.append("World");
String result = sb.toString();  // Hello World
```
lessons.expectedOutput:
Length: 19
Uppercase:   HELLO JAVA WORLD  
Trimmed: 'Hello Java World'
Contains 'Java': true

quizQuestions.text: Are strings mutable or immutable in Java?
quizQuestions.explanation: Strings are immutable; modifications create new strings.
